subject: Re: [Read_Alphabet] Letter connections and syllable boundaries (or, the spelling of "kangaroo")
msgSnippet: OK, so how should I rephrase it? Isn t LETTER /3 /, while arrest begins with /V/? (I was trying to avoid saying short U .) Ted
messageBody:
OK, so how should I rephrase it? Isn't LETTER /3\/, while 'arrest'
begins with /V/? (I was trying to avoid saying 'short U'.)

Ted


On Nov 25, 2007 7:23 AM, John Cowan <cowan@...> wrote:
>
>
>
>
>
>
> Ted Larson Freeman scripsit:
>
>
> > When writing Utter before Roe, do not connect the letters when the
> > vowel represented is in the STRUT set.
>
> Again, "arrest" does not contain any STRUT vowel, because STRUT is
> a lexical set for stressed vowels. The stressed vowel is DRESS; the
> initial unstressed vowel is LETTER.
>
>
> > PS. That's an interesting variation between our accents in the
> > pronunciation of 'kangaroo'.
>
> On reflection, At+Ing vs. Ate+Ing is yet another neutralization. *sigh*
>
> --
> As we all know, civil libertarians are not John Cowan
> the friskiest group around -- comes from cowan@...
> forever being on the qui vive for the sound http://www.ccil.org/~cowan
> of jack-booted fascism coming down the pike. --Molly Ivins
>
